utterances: She does do that?
She does, yeah.
I know her hairstylist, and she does.
She fights, Gabriele Union fights for her hairstylist.
Now, what about - does that happen with a lot of African-American women?
Because I mean, you know, you want this certain make-up on just because everybody, they're not to do African-American make-up, everybody doesn't know how to do African-American hair.
Yes.
OK.
If the actress or the talent is concerned about their look, yes, they do fight for their hair and make up team.
That is big business in America though, right now?
Oh, huge business.
The money on hair.
Huge business.
Right.
OK.
But also ladies, you know, don't be fooled by getting your hair on any and every Web site that says Indian hair.
Right.
OK.
Because what they're doing is, your hair comes from India.
Right.
Horse hair.
And on that note, we will leave this conversation.
But thank you so much.
We've learned so much today.
Thank you so much.
I'd appreciate it.

..TEXT: Ms. HAMILTON: Thank you, Allison.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That was NPR's Allison Samuels talking with celebrity stylist Marcia Hamilton here at the studios of NPR West.
You're listening to News & Notes from NPR News.
From NPR News, this is News & Notes.
I'm Tony Cox.
So, today, we continue our newcomers series showcasing some of the brightest new voices in journalism today.
This week, we head to Chicago to hear how young people fresh to the workforce are fairing in this tough economic climate.
Here's reporter Susie An.
Aileen Murphy got a job as a human resources contractor for a Chicago consulting firm after she got out of grad school.
And about 15 months into her first real job, Murphy got laid off.
At first, I handled it pretty calmly.
I sat down, I'm like, what do I need to get ready?
So, it's very strategic.
And then, once it all settled in, that's I think where I freaked out and I got really worried.
At 25, Murphy joined nearly a quarter of a million people who lost their jobs in November, and the number kept growing.
By the end of January, 7.6 percent of the nation was unemployed, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
I have never seen this level of anxiety among people and so much - I want to say hopelessness, not that it will never turn around, but that it's really going to be awhile before it turns around.
That's Arleen Hirsch.
She's been a career counselor since the early '80s and lately, she's seeing a change in her clientele.
I'm seeing a lot of young people probably graduating from college and into their mid, even late, 20s.
A lot of people I think are having trouble getting started or getting on a path.
Hirsch says young people faced a disadvantage in the job market because of a lack of experience.
The difficulty in an economic downturn then is that there are less jobs available and more qualified people.
So, it's a little bit harder for people that don't have experience because they're actually competing with people who have more experience.
But she says young people who don't have to worry about responsibilities like children or a mortgage have an advantage, and Murphy, being young and single...
I don't need the 45, $50,000 job.
I think that's a big difference for organizations.
You can get a same-level caliber candidate, but one, you know, obviously has more compensation if so.
They could get me cheaper.
It's been close to four months since Murphy lost her job.
Now, she exercises regularly, reads more books, and has reconnected with friends, all the while sending out resumes and going to interviews.
This has been an eye-opener for what I want professionally and yes, in personal aspects, too.
All in all, it's just taught me that you can never just become content with where you are.
Hirsch says that's one way people can use unemployment time to benefit themselves.
When you have some time away from that situation, you get some distance.
It's easier I think sometimes to get a little better connected with what you really want and so there's an opportunity to reevaluate.
A lot of times, people got on the wrong path or they knew it wasn't right, but they didn't know what else and so, you do have an opportunity to rethink and redirect.
For News & Notes, I'm Susie An.
It is the last day of the Bush administration.
A new cabinet is poised to reshape policy and help guide the new president.
Much like George W.
Bush in 2001, Barack Obama has assembled a group of seasoned veterans.
He has stacked the deck with a team of political heavyweights.
But are there any wild cards in that pack?
Joining us to put the new team under a microscope are Mary Frances Berry, a professor of history at the University of Pennsylvania and the former chair of the U.S.
Civil Rights Commission, and Robert George, associate editorial page editor for the New York Post.
Welcome back to News & Notes, folks.
Thanks, Tony.
Thanks, Tony.
Good to be here.
Mary, let's start with you.
Would you describe this group that the president-elect has assembled as having any unified philosophy, or is it too early to tell whether they will gel politically?
Well, I think it's too early to tell.
The most important thing about them is that Obama wanted them.
(Soundbite of laughter)
All of them.
I think that you have Clinton and Gates, who are considered to be sort of moderate hawks on war and peace matters.

You have the Treasury secretary, who still seems to me to be the most problematic one, who was part of the responsibility for the crash that is occurring and who apparently doesn't know how to do his own taxes.
And the thing of...
But that's of a wild card.

Eric Holder, who is a friend - you have a group of friends of the president, acquaintances and friends and people who play basketball and who seem superbly qualified, are mainly either ivy leaguers, or they went to major educational institutions, public and private.
And then you have people like Gates, the holdover, and Clinton and Leon Panetta at CIA, who is a - he's a Clinton holdover who used to be a Republican.
So I don't think that there is a unifying theme.
Most to them seemed to have a lot experience.
Perhaps that's a unifying theme.
Well, Robert, I want to ask you because Mr. Obama has said that he wants his team to incorporate many different perspectives and voices.
Who on the cabinet so far, at least, is most likely to represent that different voice?
All right.
Angry Republicans, who will soon be the majority in the Senate, insist there's a political cost for the president acting on his own.
Here's Texas Republican John Cornyn on the Senate floor yesterday.
